#visualization libraries
import seaborn as sns
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt 
%matplotlib inline
source.8e66e7be:
plt.figure(figsize=(16,9)) # Figure size
sns.lineplot(x='model', y='hp', data=df1, marker='o', color='indigo') 
plt.title('Horse Power') # Title
plt.xticks(df1.model.unique(), rotation=45) 
plt.show()
source.328f3c5e:
x=df1['model'].values
y=df1['hp'].values
fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize =(12, 9))   

ax.barh(x, y, color='dodgerblue', edgecolor=(0,0,0)) 
ax.set_title('Horse Power') 
plt.show()

source.5c8a1272: Horsepower correlate with cylinders, and with carburators. Miles per gallon is negatively correlated to horsepower, as well.
source.0a3860a5:
Above, is a dataframe of 15 cars close to the avg horse power of the original list.   
Their hp rages between 109 and 180.
source.83026938:
Here, horse power seems to correlate with cylinders, wt (vehicle weight), and drat
(rear axle ratio).
source.f2dd8a67:
Objectives:   

1.Explore the dataset and average value of the horsepower across all the cars.   
2.Identify correlated features.   
3.Check for outliers within the horsepower column and remove them.
